turn.text: --Which is no longer in existence, I guess.

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: --Well, you know, these contracts also recognized that possibility, too, and suggested that these provisions were binding on their successors.
But Your Honor, surely the Congress can't avoid it's contractual... or the sovereign can't avoid its contractual obligations by simply eliminating and extinguishing its agents.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask just one other--
--It does by eliminating sovereign immunity, by reinstituting sovereign immunity.

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: And Your Honor, if FIRREA had repealed the Tucker act for these purposes, I would have a much tougher case here.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask, just to save me time looking for it, you say there's... you relied heavily in the Statesman contract, the stuff on page 23.

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Where do I find the corresponding language in the Winstar contract, just so I don't--

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: Your Honor, we don't set that out in our brief because the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Because it's probably a little different.

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: --or at least the accounting principles clause... that is, the one on page 23--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But what are you relying on?

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: --is virtually identical.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Just so I know where to find the corresponding--

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Okay, at page 108 of the parties' appendix, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Okay, thank you.

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: It is marked as section 10 at the bottom of the page.
It begins there.
That's the Winstar accounting principles.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I don't want to use your time up.
I just wanted to know where it was.

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Thanks.

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: I see that my time has almost expired, so let me close by simply saying this.

The question before the Court is whether these contracting parties are simply going to remain in the places that they are, with the Government holding $24 million of my client's money in its pocket, and with my clients with a $24 million lesson in the value of the Government's solemn contractual oath.
If there are no additional questions--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Precisely what did the Government promise?

Precisely, the Government promised to let you continue to do... what it boils down to is, they promised to let you continue doing business as a bank so long as you maintained that minimum level of capital that these accounting principles would produce.
Is that the essence of the promise?

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: --They promised to calculate our regulatory capital in--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, I don't care how they calculate it.

You care that they let you continue to do business as a bank, so you're saying they gave you a sort of a charter, a promise that your bank charter wouldn't be yanked so long as you kept your capital the way these accounting principles--

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --would require.

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Mr. Cooper, if you seek damages for frustration, restitution, you still have to show a contract, don't you?
That is to say, the measure of damages doesn't particularly help us here, does it?
In either case there has to be a contract that was A, breached, or B, frustrated?

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
You at least have to show that the parties attempted but failed to enter into a binding contract.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So is the contractual inquiry and the unmistakability inquiry the same in either case, case A, breach, damages for breach, case B, restitution?

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: Your Honor, I think that even if Mr. Bender is right in everything that he says and we don't have a contract, and this effort was... died... was a failure at the closing table, and that they could have, as they say they could have, said as we left the closing table $21 million for these banks is not enough, we want more capital, and we would have no protection against that, and again he's right in everything he says, I still surely am entitled, under frustration of this effort to make a contract, to my money back.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, under what theory?
You still have to have a contract, don't you?

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: Your Honor, I think--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Can you sue the Government for unjust enrichment and restitution under the--

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.

In fact, in the final pages of our brief we cite cases that make clear that the Government can't... even if this contract was void in its beginning, it was illegal, there was no authority under FSLIC and he's right, then I am entitled at least to the return of the benefits that I've given them under the pretense of this false contract.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I think you've answered the question, Mr. Cooper.

turn.speaker: charles_j_cooper
turn.label: Mr. Charles J. Cooper
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The case is submitted.
